name: United States
controversies: There is an ongoing and highly politicized debate over raising the federal debt ceiling to avoid default, as well as concerns about the long-term sustainability of large deficits accumulated during and after the COVID-19 pandemic. The Biden administration's proposed tax reforms targeting high earners and corporate rate adjustments have sparked heated discussions on fairness, economic growth impact, and potential revenue shortfalls.
spendingEfficiency: The United States consistently ranks highly on global indicators of government effectiveness and transparency, but inefficiencies remain, particularly in the health care sector where administrative costs are among the highest worldwide. Social insurance programs are well-administered, yet overlapping welfare schemes and complex eligibility rules create administrative burdens and resource waste.

name: United Kingdom
controversies: Recent budgets have reignited controversy over planned spending cuts and proposed increases in corporation tax to close fiscal gaps. Debates over the ‘migration levy’ on employers and shifts in VAT rates for digital services and hospitality have also been contentious, drawing criticism from industry groups about competitiveness and consumer impact.
spendingEfficiency: The UK performs well on transparency and budget execution metrics, but suffers from service delivery bottlenecks in the NHS leading to long waiting times. Devolved administrations add complexity to program delivery, causing duplication of administrative functions despite high overall public sector productivity.

name: Japan
controversies: The 2019 consumption tax increase from 8% to 10% remains politically sensitive, with critics arguing it dampened household spending. Ongoing proposals to raise the retirement age and adjust pension formulas to sustain the system have faced public protests amid concerns over fairness for aging workers.
spendingEfficiency: Japan scores very high on government effectiveness indices and achieves excellent social outcomes in health and longevity, but there is recognized inefficiency in health care spending and administrative overlap across central and local governments. Streamlining these processes could yield significant savings.

revenue.name: 石油石炭税 (Sekiyu sekitan-zei, Oil & Coal Tax)
自動車重量税 (Jidōsha jūryō-zei, Vehicle Weight Tax)
電源開発促進税 (Dengen kaihatsu sokushin-zei, Electric Power Development Tax)
印紙収入 (Inshi shūnyū, Stamp Duty)

spending.name: 文教及び科学振興費 (Education & Science)
地方交付税交付金等 (Local Government Transfers)
国債費-利払費 (Interest on Debt)

name: Italy
controversies: Italy’s complex tax code fuels high levels of tax evasion, and repeated postponements of planned VAT increases to stimulate growth have raised questions about long-term fiscal stability. Pension reform proposals, including raising retirement ages and modifying benefit calculations, continue to provoke public sector strikes.
spendingEfficiency: EU and IMF assessments highlight inefficiencies due to regional budget fragmentation and bureaucratic overhead, particularly in health care and justice systems. Improving administrative digitalization and consolidating regional procurement could significantly enhance budgetary productivity.

revenue.name: IRPEF (Imposta sul reddito delle persone fisiche)
Accise su energia, tabacchi e alcoli
Imposta di registro e altri tributi minori

name: France
controversies: Pension reform raising the retirement age to 64 has sparked widespread protests and strikes. Revisions to wealth taxes and targeted VAT reductions for tourism sectors have also triggered debates over equity and budgetary impact.
spendingEfficiency: France is transparent and effective in budget execution, but the high cost of public services, especially in health and education, yields mixed performance outcomes. Streamlining spending in these sectors could further improve value for money.

revenue.name: Taxe intérieure de consommation sur les produits énergétiques (TICPE)

name: Germany
controversies: Debates around the constitutional ‘debt brake’ focus on whether to relax borrowing limits for infrastructure and green investments. The phased repeal of the Soli surcharge has also prompted discussions on replacing lost revenue without raising other taxes.
spendingEfficiency: Germany scores very high on efficiency and transparency indices; its health system delivers good outcomes at moderate cost. Challenges remain in digitalizing federal and state services to reduce redundancy and improve citizen access.

name: Canada
controversies: The federal carbon tax has been challenged by several provinces as overreaching, and debates over introducing a global minimum corporate tax have drawn industry lobbying against increased rates. Calls to expand child care subsidies also fuel discussions on where to allocate new revenues.
spendingEfficiency: Canada ranks highly for the efficiency of its health care and education spending, but provincial variations lead to uneven service delivery and duplication. Further central–provincial coordination could yield cost savings and improve access.

name: Brazil
controversies: Proposals for a comprehensive tax reform to unify multiple federal and state levies into a single value-added tax have stalled amid political disagreements. High subsidies to energy sectors and delayed pension reform continue to strain public finances and provoke legal challenges.
spendingEfficiency: Despite high social spending, outcomes in health and education lag OECD peers, reflecting inefficiencies in procurement, lack of oversight in federal transfers, and fragmentation across states. Transparency initiatives have improved data access but have yet to translate into efficiency gains.

revenue.name: Contribuição para o Financiamento da Seguridade Social (COFINS)

name: India
controversies: Implementation of the unified Goods and Services Tax (GST) encountered compliance hurdles and legal challenges from states seeking exemptions. Ongoing debates center on broadening the tax base to include informal sectors and introducing a wealth tax to boost revenues without hampering growth.
spendingEfficiency: India scores low on transparency and government effectiveness rankings, with high levels of leakage in subsidy programs and underfunded health and education systems. Digitization of welfare transfers has improved targeting but overall efficiency remains constrained by bureaucratic complexity.

name: China
controversies: Recent VAT rate reductions for small businesses have raised concerns over narrowing the tax base without compensatory revenue measures. Pilots of property taxes in select cities have faced local resistance and calls for clearer central guidelines on wealth taxation.
spendingEfficiency: China’s rapid infrastructure build-out demonstrates strong execution capacity, yet IMF reviews point to inefficiencies in overlapping local government projects and overinvestment in unprofitable state-owned enterprises. Greater transparency in budget reporting could improve resource allocation.

spending.name: 社会保障与就业支出 (Social Security and Employment)
一般公共服务支出 (General Public Services)

name: Russia
controversies: Elevated reliance on oil and gas revenues skews budget stability, while the recent VAT hike to 22% has been criticized for fueling inflation. Discussions are underway on introducing environmental and digital services taxes to diversify revenue.
spendingEfficiency: Russia’s budget transparency is low, with significant off-budget military and security expenditures. World Bank assessments point to inefficient health and education spending, hampered by bureaucratic delays and underinvestment in regional infrastructures.

revenue.name: Налог на прибыль организаций (Corporate Profit Tax)
Налог на доходы физических лиц (Personal Income Tax)

name: Mexico
controversies: The gradual corporate tax cut from 30% to 25% has sparked debate on its adequacy to stimulate investment versus the resulting revenue shortfall. The regressive nature of exemptions on basic food items under the VAT regime also remains highly contested.
spendingEfficiency: Mexico’s spending on health and education yields outcomes below OECD averages, due in part to program fragmentation across federal, state, and municipal levels. Anti-corruption measures and better performance tracking are needed to improve value-for-money.

revenue.name: Impuestos Especiales sobre Producción y Servicios (IEPS)

spending.name: Pago de Intereses de la Deuda

name: Spain
controversies: Spain’s pension system currently runs a structural deficit—as of 2024 absorbing about 25 % of public spending—due to a declining worker-to-retiree ratio. Recent income-tax bracket adjustments favoring middle earners have prompted concerns over fairness and revenue stability, while proposed regional wealth taxes on high-net-worth individuals remain the subject of ongoing debate.
spendingEfficiency: Spain’s universal health and education systems are well-ranked for coverage, but inefficiencies persist in hospital wait times and regional disparities in school performance. The OCDE recommends stronger program evaluation frameworks to redirect funding to highest-impact areas.

revenue.name: Impuesto sobre la Renta de las Personas Físicas (IRPF)

spending.name: Pago de Intereses de la Deuda

name: Ireland
controversies: Ireland’s heavy reliance on corporate tax—88% paid by foreign multinationals, with the top 10 firms contributing 57% of receipts—has drawn EU scrutiny and highlighted vulnerability to U.S. policy shifts. Domestic debates over housing affordability and water charges continue to spark protests.
spendingEfficiency: Ireland’s universal healthcare faces long waiting lists for elective procedures, driving uptake of private insurance; social housing delivery lags, exacerbating homelessness and fueling voter frustration over public service quality. The OECD recommends streamlining hospital capacity planning and enhancing procurement frameworks to boost impact per euro spent.

name: Australia

national_incidents.title: North Queensland Floods
national_incidents.description: Extreme rainfall and riverine flooding across North Queensland from 29 January to 28 February 2025 displaced thousands and caused widespread infrastructure damage. The federal government declared a disaster and deployed emergency relief efforts; most communities had returned to normal by March.

controversies: Australia’s gradual 'stage three' personal tax cuts, due from July 2024, have drawn criticism for favoring higher-income earners and risking further bracket creep; debates over federal-state health funding and water rights in the Murray–Darling basin remain highly contentious.
spendingEfficiency: Despite high per-capita health expenditure, public hospital wait times and elective surgery backlogs remain among the longest in the OECD; infrastructure project cost overruns (e.g. Melbourne Metro, WestConnex) highlight weaknesses in project evaluation and procurement processes.

name: Austria
controversies: Pension reform in Austria is debated due to rising costs, with expenditures set to reach 15% of GDP by 2030. Key issues include raising the retirement age, linking it to life expectancy, and cutting benefits, which may impact vulnerable groups. Without reform, future pension spending will continue to grow.
spendingEfficiency: Austria’s healthcare system ranks highly for outcomes but faces challenges with cost containment and regional disparities; education performance is strong though the OECD recommends enhanced vocational training pathways.

name: Peru
organizations: Community of Latin American and Caribbean States
controversies: High presidential turnover and continuous cabinet changes in 2023-2024 have undermined confidence in institutional stability, prompting debates on far-reaching political reforms.
spendingEfficiency: Although health and education coverage is extensive, logistical bottlenecks persist in the Andean and Amazonian regions, and the OECD recommends improving programme evaluation to optimise resources.

name: Hungary
controversies: Ongoing rule-of-law disputes with the EU over judicial independence, media freedom and electoral reforms, leading to conditional budget disbursements under the Recovery and Resilience Facility.
spendingEfficiency: Healthcare outcomes outperform spending levels but suffer regional inequalities; PISA scores remain below the OECD average, with calls to strengthen vocational training.

name: Bulgaria
controversies: High levels of perceived corruption in public procurement and slow judicial reforms have repeatedly triggered EU infringement procedures and conditional funding clauses.
spendingEfficiency: Healthcare indicators lag regional peers despite moderate spending; recent PISA performance is improving but vocational pathways remain underdeveloped.

name: Croatia
controversies: Slow judicial reform and backlog in the European Court of Human Rights, as well as tourism‐driven housing pressures, have sparked social and EU‐level debates.
spendingEfficiency: Healthcare outcomes are on par with regional EU peers; educational reform is in progress to boost STEM and vocational training.

name: Belgium
controversies: Belgium’s budget deficit rose to 4.6% of GDP in 2024, risking EU rule violations and drawing criticism for poor fiscal coordination. Controversy surrounds reclassifying infrastructure and frozen assets to meet NATO defence targets. Meanwhile, Brussels is under scrutiny after a Huawei-linked EU bribery probe exposed lobbying and transparency failures.
spendingEfficiency: Belgium spends over 54% of GDP on public services, among the highest in the OECD, but with limited efficiency, especially in healthcare, long-term care, and education. The OECD and IMF urge comprehensive spending reviews, better digital tools, and stricter coordination between federal and regional governments to improve value-for-money and reduce wasteful outlays.

name: Cyprus
controversies: Cyprus’s main public‐spending woes are an inflated wage bill (especially in education) and meagre R&D investment; a costly “golden passports” VAT fraud; major procurement scandals (a €542 M LNG terminal and a €46 M waste‐treatment plant); and weak oversight, seen in the Auditor‐General’s dismissal and dwindling tender competition
spendingEfficiency: Cyprus spends 40 % of GDP, with strong governance and a falling debt ratio, but efficiency is limited by weak procurement, poor SOE oversight, and low R&D and environmental investment. Reforms like accrual accounting and digital services are improving transparency, but challenges remain despite credit-rating upgrades.

name: Czech Republic
controversies: Despite generally strong institutions, the Czech Republic contends with recurring procurement and corruption scandals—most notably the 2025 Motol Hospital bribery case and EU subsidy fraud allegations against prominent political figures—underscoring weaknesses in public contracting and delayed anti-corruption reforms.
spendingEfficiency: Government spending runs at about 43.7% of GDP, supported by falling debt, accrual accounting, and expanding digital services; however, efficiency is undermined by weak procurement oversight, low R&D investment (~2% of GDP), and ongoing integrity challenges in public contracting.

name: Denmark
spendingEfficiency: Denmark consistently ranks among the top OECD countries for converting public funds into high-quality services, thanks to its rigorous, centrally coordinated spending reviews that target genuine efficiency gains rather than across-the-board cuts. Its procurement system, representing roughly 14 % of GDP, is guided by transparent rules and digital oversight, ensuring value for money and minimal waste. Public investment levels hover around the OECD average, with capital projects regularly re-evaluated to maximize long-term returns.

revenue.name: Udbytter og indtægter fra offentlige virksomheder

name: Estonia
controversies: Estonia’s defence budget row erupted in late 2024 when a €1.6 billion ammunition package and the resignation of Permanent Secretary Kusti Salm laid bare weaknesses in parliamentary oversight. The transition to a voluntary second-pillar pension scheme at the start of 2024 unleashed a liquidity surge equal to nearly 5 % of GDP, prompting warnings of economic overheating and intergenerational unfairness. Justice Minister Kalle Laanet’s sudden spring 2024 resignation over a €12,000 state-funded rental expense scandal highlighted ethics and transparency lapses at the highest level.
spendingEfficiency: Estonia’s public finances are characterized by a lean government structure and a strong commitment to digital innovation, which together enable the country to deliver high-quality services at relatively low cost. By keeping overall spending below the OECD average and harnessing pioneering e-governance platforms, Estonia minimizes administrative overhead and streamlines citizen access to services. In healthcare, despite only moderate expenditure, Estonia achieves outcomes that rival those of wealthier peers.

name: Finland
spendingEfficiency: Finland is widely recognized for its high-quality public services, with citizen satisfaction levels well above OECD averages. Its governance and stakeholder engagement in budgeting are strong, though green budgeting and healthcare efficiency need improvement. The well-being services counties, which now manage healthcare, face rising deficits, challenging sustainability. The OECD urges Finland to enhance cost-effectiveness, especially in these regions. Overall, public spending remains effective, but fiscal pressures are mounting.
controversies: In 2024, Finland breached EU debt and deficit limits, sparking heated debate over planned spending cuts and tax hikes. Over half of the country’s new healthcare counties admitted they cannot meet legal budget balance deadlines, with some refusing to comply. The government faces criticism for failing to provide realistic funding or flexibility. At the same time, Finland’s €9.6 billion F-35 fighter jet deal raised concerns over underestimated operating costs. Together, these issues highlight deepening fiscal tensions despite Finland’s reputation for sound governance.

name: Greece
controversies: Greece’s bid in April 2025 to exempt €500 million of defence spending from the EU’s 3 % deficit ceiling reignited debate over fiscal discipline versus security needs. In May 2025, revelations of opaque contracts between the ruling New Democracy party and a PR firm spurred calls for an independent probe into campaign-finance and procurement breaches. Meanwhile, endemic “envelope” bribery—spotlighted by a Rhodes planning officer raid—alongside a national civil-service strike in November 2024 and fresh EU cohesion-funds oversight concerns have all underscored deep governance challenges.
spendingEfficiency: Despite solid growth, Greece’s fragmented social-benefit system and heavy tilt toward current consumption hamper long-term returns on public outlays. A debt-to-GDP ratio near 162 % further constrains fiscal leeway and heightens market vulnerability. Consistently low scores in global government-efficiency and economic-freedom indices reflect lingering bureaucracy, red-tape hurdles and widespread tax evasion that erode both revenue mobilisation and public trust.

name: Latvia
spendingEfficiency: Latvia continues to face challenges with public spending efficiency, especially in healthcare, pensions, and internal security. International institutions urge better targeting of social aid and strategic tax shifts to improve outcomes. Recent reforms to budget planning have laid a foundation for improved control and oversight. However, maximizing EU fund absorption remains critical to support growth without increasing deficits.
controversies: The Rail Baltica project's cost explosion to nearly €10 billion has sparked outrage, with lawmakers calling it a major fiscal failure. Defence prepayments caused unexpected budget deficits in early 2025, raising questions about spending priorities. Latvia's rapid expenditure growth has also drawn EU warnings over breaching deficit thresholds. These controversies reflect deeper governance and accountability issues in managing public funds.

name: Lithuania
spendingEfficiency: Lithuania faces persistent inefficiencies in public spending, especially in healthcare, with high preventable deaths and low outcomes despite moderate funding. The shadow economy and aging population strain finances, prompting calls for reforms like digital tax systems, better spending reviews, and boosting property tax revenues.
controversies: Major scandals in 2024–2025 exposed deep flaws in Lithuania’s public finance oversight, from fintech-linked laundering and rigged tenders to large-scale embezzlement and bribery in state agencies. These incidents triggered resignations, EU-level investigations, and demands for stronger regulatory and ethical safeguards.

name: Luxembourg
spendingEfficiency: Luxembourg maintains a high level of public service delivery while keeping total spending below the OECD average, signaling efficient use of resources. Strong investment in infrastructure and digitalization reflects strategic prioritization. Public procurement practices are well-aligned with international standards. The push for performance-based budgeting aims to further enhance fiscal accountability.
controversies: Recent fiscal controversies have raised concerns about oversight and transparency in Luxembourg’s public spending. A €61 million embezzlement scandal within Caritas Luxembourg shook public confidence. The EU flagged the 2024 budget for breaching spending growth limits. Continued broad subsidies and rising fraud investigations have intensified scrutiny of fiscal governance.

revenue.name: Impôt sur le revenu des personnes physiques
Impôt sur le revenu des collectivités

name: Malta
organizations: Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe
spendingEfficiency: Malta continues to underperform relative to its EU peers, with non‐parametric analysis placing its efficiency score at just 0.38—suggesting that over 60 % of current outlays could be trimmed without jeopardizing core service delivery. Recent IMF assessments emphasize the need for a full Public Investment Management Assessment alongside the digitalization of procurement to secure better value in infrastructure and health projects. Strategic measures in the 2025 Budget target reductions in energy subsidies and non-essential recurrent spending while shielding social transfers, aiming to streamline expenditure and improve fiscal sustainability.
controversies: High-profile scandals have shaken Malta’s public finances, notably the self-suspension of the Central Bank governor—formerly finance minister—amid fraud allegations linked to a 2015 hospitals privatization ruled fraudulent by Maltese courts. The €15 million settlement by Steward Health Care over a disputed hospital concession highlighted opaque practices in public–private deals . Meanwhile, the European Public Prosecutor’s Office has brought charges against customs officers and intermediaries in a major fraud and corruption probe, underlining systemic procurement and revenue-collection weaknesses.

name: Netherlands
spendingEfficiency: The Netherlands is recognized for its highly efficient public spending, underpinned by rigorous processes such as systematic spending reviews and a sophisticated public procurement framework. With procurement accounting for over 20% of GDP—well above the OECD average—the Dutch government leverages its institutional maturity to ensure value for money across sectors. Longstanding practices of evaluating and adjusting budget programs have helped sustain fiscal discipline while maintaining high-quality public services. Despite emerging pressures from an ageing population and climate-related investments, the country’s prudent management has generally allowed for well-targeted and effective use of public funds.
controversies: Despite its reputation for fiscal prudence, the Netherlands has recently faced growing criticism over its budget trajectory. In 2024, it was singled out as the only EU country to fail the European Commission’s deficit-and-debt test for 2025, casting doubt on the credibility of its spending plans. Political tensions have also flared over steep cuts to overseas aid and the prospect of major increases in defence expenditure to meet NATO commitments. A new right-leaning coalition has prioritized deficit reduction, but its approach has sparked controversy at home and in Brussels, exposing deep divides over how to balance fiscal rules with evolving geopolitical and social priorities.

name: Poland
spendingEfficiency: Poland has made some strides in aligning its budgetary outlays with strategic priorities, yet efficiency gains remain uneven across sectors. While the government has introduced a framework for spending reviews and medium-term expenditure ceilings, the actual reallocation of resources toward high-impact areas—especially healthcare and defence—has been limited. Demographic pressures, notably an ageing population and rising pension commitments, further strain public finances, underscoring the need for more rigorous cost-benefit analyses and performance-based budgeting to ensure that each zloty spent delivers measurable social and economic returns.
controversies: Recent years have seen Poland enmeshed in high-profile disputes over the use and oversight of public funds. Allegations of “suspected illegal spending” under the former administration have led to criminal investigations into hundreds of officials and potential irregularities amounting to tens of billions of zlotys. Brussels has also flexed its conditionality powers, withholding and imposing fines on EU budget transfers in response to rule-of-law concerns, while procurement integrity disputes and debates over defence spending thresholds highlight ongoing challenges in transparency and accountability.

name: Portugal
spendingEfficiency: Portugal has made gradual progress in improving public spending efficiency, largely under pressure from the European Union and the OECD. Reforms have focused on institutionalizing spending reviews, particularly in social protection, health and education, and on introducing performance-based budgeting. Despite these steps, inefficiencies remain widespread—especially in procurement processes and digital infrastructure management. International bodies continue to urge Portugal to broaden its expenditure reviews and strengthen links between spending and outcomes to better support long-term fiscal sustainability.
controversies: In the past two years, Portugal has faced a wave of fiscal scandals that have shaken its political system. The most prominent include Operation Influencer, a corruption probe into lithium and hydrogen contracts that implicated top government officials, and a major IT-procurement investigation involving multiple public institutions. Political fallout from ethics violations led to the collapse of the minority government in early 2025, while tensions over tax policies nearly derailed the 2025 budget. At the same time, controversies over state aid to TAP Air Portugal and a sharp drop in the budget surplus have raised fresh concerns about transparency and financial discipline.

revenue.name: Imposto sobre o Rendimento das Pessoas Singulares (IRS)
Imposto sobre o Rendimento das Pessoas Coletivas (IRC)

name: Slovakia
spendingEfficiency: Slovakia’s public‑spending efficiency falls below EU‑27 and OECD averages due to persistently low absorption of EU funds, weak oversight and fragmented appraisal—especially in transport projects leading to overruns—and a World Bank DEA analysis confirms it lags peer “smart” OECD countries in delivering value for money.
controversies: Bratislava’s 2024 judicial reforms, which dissolved key anti‑corruption bodies and reduced penalties for financial crime, led the EU to suspend €799 million in grants; at the same time, MEPs and the EPPO are investigating alleged nepotism and fraud in EU‑subsidised agricultural estates, accusing authorities of diverting CAP funds to private interests.

name: Slovenia
spendingEfficiency: Slovenia’s public spending in 2024–25 has been hampered by opaque procurement practices, cost overruns in flood reconstruction, systemic corruption losses estimated at up to 7.5% of GDP annually, and insufficient oversight in law‑enforcement funding, all of which have eroded value for taxpayers
controversies: The key scandals include the 2024 ‘Laptopgate’ procurement of outdated school laptops, budget overruns in the €1.1 billion flood‑reconstruction programme, persistent high‑level corruption losses, the early 2025 police Special Unit misconduct scandal, and the politically charged 2024 EU Commissioner nomination fallout

revenue.name: Prispevki za pokojninsko in invalidsko zavarovanje

name: Serbia
controversies: Several major 2024–25 episodes—like the €3.5 billion Belgrade Waterfront deal approved by special decree, the $500 million Jared Kushner hotel lease tainted by forged heritage‑protection documents, a €4.8 million luxury hotel subsidy questioned for poor job creation, the U.S. withdrawal of $14 million procurement reform aid after missed milestones, and secretive emergency medical equipment contracts awarded without open tender—have sparked legal investigations, parliamentary inquiries and widespread public criticism over opaque decision‑making and governance failures.
spendingEfficiency: In each case, public money delivered little measurable return: flagship investments remain stalled or legally frozen, promised procurement savings evaporated, small‑scale subsidies lacked clear cost‑benefit analysis, and emergency purchases remain unaccounted, demonstrating weak oversight, absent transparency and low spending efficiency overall.

name: Norway
organizations: Organisation for Economic Co‑operation and Development (OECD)
controversies: In 2024–25, Norway faced criticism over expanded oil and gas licensing in the Arctic, sparking environmental protests and legal challenges; parliamentary scrutiny of sovereign wealth fund withdrawals to cover budget deficits amid market volatility; investigations into alleged local fish‑farm pollution in Western fjords; and debates over pension reform delays leading to equity concerns for younger workers.
spendingEfficiency: Despite robust per‑capita spending on health and education, outcomes have shown stagnating waiting‑times in specialised care, mixed performance on PISA scores, and cost‑overruns on rail infrastructure projects, indicating persistent challenges in translating high public investment into commensurate service improvements.

name: Switzerland
controversies: Recent 2024-25 Swiss governance challenges include the controversial CHF 4 billion UBS-Credit Suisse emergency merger that prompted parliamentary investigations into financial oversight failures, several contentious weapon export permits to conflict regions worth CHF 955 million despite neutrality concerns, a CHF 1.2 billion public procurement scandal with alleged insider favoritism in healthcare IT contracts, and criticism over secretive bilateral agreements with China worth approximately CHF 2 billion that bypassed traditional democratic scrutiny processes.
spendingEfficiency: While Switzerland maintains generally high public spending efficiency, several recent issues have emerged: the CHF 4 billion financial sector intervention created moral hazard concerns while protecting systemic stability, defense procurement programs experienced a 15% cost overrun averaging CHF 230 million per project, cantonal healthcare subsidies showed uneven cost-benefit outcomes with 30% variance in administrative overhead ratios, and infrastructure projects faced an average 18-month delay and 22% budget increases due to complex stakeholder consultation requirements.

name: Sweden
controversies: Sweden's 2024 policy shifts include controversial immigration reforms introducing stricter family reunification requirements and temporary residency permits, NATO membership formalization despite historical neutrality, and nuclear energy expansion with SEK 400 billion investment plans causing environmental protests. Urban safety concerns intensified after gang violence in Stockholm and Malmö suburbs, prompting a SEK 1.5 billion police funding boost but raising civil liberties questions about expanded surveillance powers.
spendingEfficiency: Recent evaluations reveal mixed spending efficiency outcomes: the SEK 30 billion healthcare digitalization initiative faced implementation delays with 40% cost overruns, climate adaptation funds remained partially unallocated (SEK 5 billion), while the comprehensive education reform successfully streamlined vocational training with 22% improved employment outcomes. Municipal spending autonomy continues creating regional disparities, with efficiency audits showing northern regions achieving 15-20% lower service delivery per krona spent compared to southern regions.

name: Iceland
controversies: Iceland's 2024-25 policy challenges include the controversial ISK 30 billion geothermal expansion project facing indigenous land rights disputes, a ISK 5.6 billion tourism infrastructure initiative criticized for weak environmental impact assessments, and an offshore wind development program that bypassed standard public consultation processes. Ongoing investigations probe emergency COVID equipment procurements made without competitive bidding, while a parliamentary inquiry examines the ISK 2 billion digital infrastructure grant allocated through expedited procedures with limited transparency.
spendingEfficiency: Independent assessments indicate mixed fiscal performance: healthcare investments delivered measurable service improvements with 12% shorter wait times, while housing subsidies failed to appreciably improve affordability despite ISK 7 billion allocation. Transportation projects routinely exceed budgets by 25-40%, and the ISK 3.5 billion digital governance initiative faces significant implementation delays. Public spending reviews identified approximately ISK 9 billion in potential efficiency gains through program consolidation and improved procurement practices.

name: Ukraine

national_incidents.title: Largest Drone Attack Since 2022 Hits Ukraine
national_incidents.description: On May 18, 2025, Russia deployed 273 explosive and decoy drones, killing one woman and injuring three others in its largest drone offensive to date.

controversies: Ukraine's 2024-25 governance challenges include the ₴12 billion defense procurement program facing scrutiny over expedited contracts with limited competition, the ₴8.4 billion reconstruction initiative with questioned contractor selection processes, and emergency power infrastructure repairs awarded through special wartime provisions bypassing standard oversight. International aid utilization faces monitoring challenges with approximately ₴40 billion in assistance flowing through various channels with differing transparency requirements, while the ₴5 billion digital transformation program operates under special wartime provisions with streamlined procurement procedures.
spendingEfficiency: Under wartime conditions, spending efficiency shows mixed outcomes: emergency reconstruction delivers critical infrastructure repairs at 20-30% premium cost but in accelerated timeframes, defense spending necessarily prioritizes speed over optimal procurement practices, while civilian sector funding achieves varied efficiency - healthcare digital transformation shows measurable 15% service improvements despite challenging conditions, but housing assistance programs struggle with delivery mechanisms and coordination. International partner organizations note substantial progress in transparency systems despite wartime pressures, with approximately 75% of non-security spending now tracked in public procurement portals.

revenue.name: Податок на доходи фізичних осіб / Personal Income Tax
Податок на прибуток підприємств / Corporate Tax

name: Belarus
controversies: Belarus's governance challenges in 2024-25 include the 3.5 billion BYN state enterprise support program criticized for lack of transparent allocation criteria, state media funding of 450 million BYN without clear performance metrics, and a 1.2 billion BYN infrastructure development initiative with procurement processes largely shielded from public scrutiny. The 800 million BYN IT sector development fund faces questions about selective benefits to politically connected firms, while international sanctions compliance monitoring reveals limited transparency in state procurement for strategic sectors with approximately 6 billion BYN in expenditures operating through specialized procurement channels with minimal public reporting.
spendingEfficiency: State audits reveal mixed efficiency outcomes across sectors: social housing initiatives delivered 22% below targeted unit production despite full budget execution, transportation infrastructure projects averaged 35% cost overruns with limited explanation for variances, while healthcare equipment modernization achieved stated delivery targets but with minimal performance improvement metrics. The state enterprise support program's economic impact assessment identified approximately 1.8 billion BYN in subsidies generating negligible productivity improvements, while digital government initiatives show partial implementation success with approximately 40% of allocated resources delivering measurable service improvements.

name: Bosnia and Herzegovina
controversies: Bosnia and Herzegovina's governance challenges in 2024-25 include the 350 million BAM infrastructure development program facing implementation fragmentation across entity jurisdictions, the 120 million BAM public administration reform initiative stalled by entity-level disagreements over implementation authority, and a 75 million BAM energy sector investment program with procurement irregularities identified by independent monitors. The European Union suspended 95 million BAM in sectoral funding following missed reform milestones, while international observers documented approximately 180 million BAM in entity-level procurements conducted with limited transparency and questionable competitive procedures.
spendingEfficiency: External assessments highlight significant efficiency challenges in public spending: administrative duplication between state and entity levels consumes approximately 15% of total governance expenditure, infrastructure projects routinely face 30-40% cost overruns and implementation delays averaging 18 months, while social protection programs show significant targeting inefficiencies with approximately 70 million BAM in benefits not reaching intended recipients. Entity-level differences in procurement practices create significant price disparities for comparable goods and services, while fragmented IT systems prevent comprehensive spending analysis and oversight across governance levels.

name: North Macedonia
controversies: North Macedonia's governance challenges in 2024-25 include the 7.5 billion MKD transportation infrastructure program facing procurement irregularities identified by state auditors, the 2.8 billion MKD renewable energy subsidies awarded through procedures lacking clear evaluation criteria, and 900 million MKD in digital infrastructure contracts with limited competitive bidding. Anti-corruption investigators launched inquiries into the 550 million MKD hospital equipment procurement process after whistleblower allegations, while European Commission progress reports highlighted approximately 3.5 billion MKD in public expenditures with documentation deficiencies indicating potential governance weaknesses.
spendingEfficiency: Independent assessments reveal mixed spending efficiency: education sector reforms achieved 15% improvement in technical education outcomes despite implementation delays, healthcare modernization projects delivered approximately 60% of targeted service improvements while consuming full budget allocation, and social housing initiatives completed only 45% of planned units despite 85% budget execution. Municipal-level spending shows significant efficiency variance, with top-performing local governments delivering comparable services at 25-30% lower cost than worst performers, while national infrastructure projects face persistent challenges with cost containment and implementation timelines, averaging 35% budget overruns.

revenue.name: Данок на личен доход / Personal Income Tax

spending.name: Јавен ред и безбедност / Public Safety

name: Albania
controversies: Albania's governance challenges in 2024-25 include the 15 billion ALL infrastructure development program flagged for procurement irregularities by state auditors, the 8.5 billion ALL tourism development initiative criticized for weak environmental impact assessments, and a 3.2 billion ALL energy sector modernization project facing transparency concerns regarding contractor selection. An EU-funded evaluation identified approximately 7 billion ALL in public-private partnership arrangements with questionable value-for-money assessments, while the State Supreme Audit institution flagged 2.8 billion ALL in public expenditures with insufficient documentation or procurement irregularities across multiple ministries.
spendingEfficiency: Independent assessments reveal mixed spending efficiency outcomes: healthcare system reforms achieved approximately 60% of targeted service improvements despite full budget utilization, education modernization projects delivered measurable outcomes in digital literacy but with significant regional disparities in implementation, and public infrastructure projects routinely face 25-35% cost overruns with implementation delays averaging 14 months. Municipal spending shows significant variance in efficiency, with comparable services delivered at costs differing by up to 40% between similar-sized municipalities, while EU pre-accession funds demonstrate higher implementation and outcome achievement rates compared to nationally-funded programs.

name: Montenegro
controversies: Montenegro's governance challenges in 2024-25 include the €250 million highway construction project facing cost overruns and transparency concerns, the €85 million tourism development initiative criticized for environmental impact assessment shortcomings, and a €30 million energy infrastructure program with procurement procedures flagged by independent monitors. The European Commission progress report highlighted approximately €120 million in public expenditures with insufficient documentation or procedural irregularities, while state auditors identified roughly €45 million in questionable public-private partnership arrangements lacking comprehensive value-for-money assessments and proper risk allocation mechanisms.
spendingEfficiency: Independent assessments indicate mixed spending efficiency: public administration reforms delivered approximately 40% of targeted efficiency improvements despite full budget utilization, infrastructure projects routinely face 30-40% cost overruns and implementation delays averaging 16 months, while EU pre-accession funded initiatives show higher implementation rates and outcome achievement compared to nationally-funded programs. Municipal spending demonstrates significant variance in efficiency, with comparable services delivered at costs differing by up to 35% between similar-sized municipalities, while sectoral spending reviews identified approximately €35 million in potential savings through consolidation of overlapping programs and improved procurement practices.

spending.name: Javni red i bezbjednost / Public Safety

name: Moldova
controversies: Moldova's governance challenges in 2024-25 include the 1.2 billion MDL transportation infrastructure program with procurement irregularities identified by state auditors, the 450 million MDL energy security initiative implemented through emergency procedures with limited competitive bidding, and 320 million MDL in agricultural subsidy programs with questioned targeting criteria and oversight mechanisms. International partners raised concerns about approximately 750 million MDL in public expenditures with inadequate documentation or procedural compliance, while the energy sector audit identified roughly 280 million MDL in contracts awarded without proper competitive procedures or value-for-money assessments.
spendingEfficiency: Independent assessments reveal mixed spending efficiency: public administration reforms achieved approximately 50% of targeted improvements while consuming full budget allocations, infrastructure projects routinely face 25-35% cost overruns and implementation delays averaging 14 months, while EU-supported programs demonstrate higher implementation rates and outcome achievement compared to nationally-funded initiatives. Sectoral spending reviews identified approximately 650 million MDL in potential savings through improved procurement practices and program consolidation, while municipal spending shows significant variance in efficiency with comparable services delivered at costs differing by up to 40% between similar-sized localities.
